application_protocol.purpose: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application protocol (AP) for the exchange of functional data and their schematic representation for process plant. Functional data includes the functional design of systems, and the engineering specifications of system components to be used for subsequent procurement or component design.
application_protocol.keywords: application protocol, functional data, schematic representation, process plant, system

li.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application protocol (AP) for the exchange of functional data and their schematic representation for process plant. Functional data includes the functional design of systems, and the engineering specifications of system components to be used for subsequent procurement or component design.

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application protocol (AP) for the functional design of systems within a process plant, and for the engineering specifications of system components to be used for subsequent procurement or component design.

The principal activities that take place during the life of a process plant, and the flows of information and material between them, are shown in Figure 1. The two activities, which are principally addressed by this application protocol are:
The schema for this part of ISO 10303 is specified by reference to the application module that is appropriate to the conformance class, as defined in clause 6.
Each module references further modules. The hierarchy of module dependencies defined by these references is shown in the module dependence diagrams in Technical discussion.
There is a substantial overlap in scope between this part of ISO 10303 and ISO 10303-227. The overlap in scope is summarised by Figure 2.

li.p: functional data about a physical object within a process plant;
Functional data includes:
A physical object within a process plant can be:

ul.li: a component of a system or of a plant item;
a batch of process or utility material;
a stream of process or utility material.

example.p: Crude oil is a process material.
Cooling water is a utility material.

li.p: Systems within scope include:

ul.li: systems that handle process materials and utility materials;
safety, health and environmental control and monitoring systems;
electrical power generation, transmission and distribution systems with a process plant.

example.p: A lubricating oil system is an auxiliary system for an equipment item.

li.p: Plant items and components within scope include:

ul.li: process equipment (vessels, columns, reactors, pumps, compressors, heat exchangers, boilers, furnaces, storage tanks, etc.), and their auxiliary systems;
instrumentation items (control and safety/relief valves, gauges, thermocouples, etc);
safety health and environmental system hardware (intrusion alarms, site access controls, weigh bridges, fire alarms, building automation systems, HVAC, smoke detectors, sniffers, etc).

li.p: the specification of an activity carried out by a system within a process plant;
A specification of an activity includes:

ul.li: connectivity, where information or material flows from one activity to another;
the involvement of systems, plant items and components, batches and streams of material, people and organisations in an activity.

li.p: Activities within scope include:

example.p: A chemical reaction is a transformation.
A flow through a pipe or wire, or via a conveyor belt, is a transportation.
The heating of a fluid is a change.
The storage of a liquid is a holding activity.

li.p: schematic diagram;
A symbol on a diagram can be linked to a physical object or activity.

note.p: The link between a symbol on a schematic and a physical object or activity makes the schematic 'intelligent'. An application can use this link to support access to data about the physical object or activity by clicking on the symbol.

li.p: Diagrams within scope include:
reference data library;
A reference data library of classes can be used to specify the nature of:

ul.li: an individual document, organisation or person;
a composition or connection relationship between physical objects or activities;
the involvement of a physical object, document, organisation or person in an activity.

note.p: This part of ISO 10303 can be used to store a reference data library of classes. This part of ISO 10303 can also reference to a library of classes. The referenced library of classes can be stored in the format defined by this part of ISO 10303 or any other format which gives each class within the library a unique identifier.

li.p: This part of ISO 10303 can make reference to the reference data library defined by ISO 10303-4. This part of ISO 10303 can also reference a library of standard parts held in accordance with ISO 13582.
person and organisation.
Information about a person or organisation includes:

ul.li: the involvment of a person or organisation in an activity.

li.p: conceptual process design, using process simulators;
simulation or functional testing of systems;
3D shape representation of the plant items, and their spatial configuration in a 3D model;

note.p: This is in the scope of ISO 10303-227.

li.p: detailed building automation installation information;

note.p: This is in the scope of ISO 10303-212 and ISO 10303-225.

li.p: detailed physical design of process controls and monitoring systems and of electrotechnical systems;

note.p: This is in the scope of ISO 10303-212. However, the conceptual functional and physical design of process controls and monitoring systems and of electrotechnical systems is also in the scope of this part of ISO 10303.

li.p: information about the plant infrastructure (buildings, steel structures, concrete structures, roads, platforms, ladders, etc);
management and cost information related to procurement and construction;
information related to plant operations and maintenance.
